bibl.title: Military Orders for Walter Reed, January 17, 1901

div1.p: Sternberg recommends that Reed be sent back to Washington, D.C. from Havana, Cuba, in order to continue his investigation into yellow fever at the Army Medical Museum. [Courtesy of the National Archives and Records Administration]

div1.head: Military Orders for Walter Reed, January 17, 1901
div1.opener:
Communications on official business should be addressed “To the Surgeon General, U. S. Army, Washington, D. C.”
Subject: Change of Station.
In reply refer to No.
150 -90
WAR DEPARTMENT,
Surgeon General's Office,
Washington, January 17, 1901.
To the
ADJUTANT GENERAL OF THE ARMY.
Sir:
div1.p:
I have the honor to recommend that Major Walter Reed, Surgeon,
U.S. Army, be ordered to proceed from Columbia Barracks, Cuba, to
this city, upon the adjournment of the Pan-American Medical Congress,
Havana, Cuba, to which he is a delegate by virtue of paragraph 21,
S.O. 302, A.G.O., December 27, 1900, for the purpose of continuing,
in the laboratory of the Army Medical Museum, this city, his investi-
gation with reference to the cause and prevention of yellow fever.
div1.closer: Very respectfully, G.M. Sternberg Surgeon General, U.S. Army.
